title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
overview: A novel about the serious issues of rape and racial inequality, seen through the eyes of a young girl in 1930s Alabama.

author: George Orwell
overview: A dystopian social science fiction novel that warns of the dangers of totalitarianism.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
overview: A romantic novel about the emotional development of Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates love, reputation, and misunderstandings.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
overview: A critique of the American Dream set in the Roaring Twenties, focusing on wealth, obsession, and tragedy.

title: Moby Dick
author: Herman Melville
overview: An epic tale of obsession and revenge as Captain Ahab seeks the elusive white whale.

title: War and Peace
author: Leo Tolstoy
overview: A historical novel that delves into the lives of five aristocratic families during Napoleon's invasion of Russia.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
overview: A novel about teenage rebellion and alienation as narrated by the cynical Holden Caulfield.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
overview: The fantastical journey of Bilbo Baggins as he is thrust into an adventure with dwarves to reclaim their homeland.

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Ray Bradbury
overview: A dystopian novel where books are banned, and 'firemen' burn them, questioning the role of censorship in society.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
overview: A dystopian future where individuality is suppressed in favor of a caste system based on genetic engineering.

title: The Alchemist
author: Paulo Coelho
overview: A philosophical novel about Santiago, a shepherd on a journey to discover his personal legend.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
author: Oscar Wilde
overview: A novel exploring the consequences of vanity and moral corruption as Dorian Gray seeks eternal youth.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
overview: A psychological exploration of a man who commits murder and struggles with guilt and redemption.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
overview: A complex exploration of faith, doubt, free will, and morality through the lives of three brothers.

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Alexandre Dumas
overview: A thrilling tale of an innocent man wrongfully imprisoned, his escape, and his quest for vengeance.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Brontë
overview: A classic coming-of-age novel that explores themes of love, morality, and independence through the life of an orphan.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
author: John Steinbeck
overview: A powerful depiction of the hardships faced by migrant farmers during the Great Depression.

title: Little Women
author: Louisa May Alcott
overview: The lives of four sisters growing up during the Civil War and their journey from childhood to adulthood.

title: The Bell Jar
author: Sylvia Plath
overview: A semi-autobiographical novel about a young woman’s battle with mental illness in the 1950s.

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Emily Brontë
overview: A passionate and tragic love story set on the desolate Yorkshire moors.

title: The Road
author: Cormac McCarthy
overview: A harrowing post-apocalyptic novel about a father and son's struggle to survive.

title: The Fault in Our Stars
author: John Green
overview: A poignant story of two teenagers who fall in love while dealing with the effects of terminal illness.

title: The Handmaid's Tale
author: Margaret Atwood
overview: A dystopian novel set in a theocratic society where women’s rights are severely restricted.

title: The Kite Runner
author: Khaled Hosseini
overview: A story of friendship, betrayal, and redemption set against the backdrop of a changing Afghanistan.

title: The Old Man and the Sea
author: Ernest Hemingway
overview: A short novel about an aging fisherman’s epic battle with a giant marlin.

title: The Secret Garden
author: Frances Hodgson Burnett
overview: A children’s novel about a young girl who discovers a hidden, magical garden.
